user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

This is an example of discharge summary letter:
Dear ___,

You came into hospital because you were getting more short of breath and your ankles were swollen.

A heart scan, called an echocardiogram, showed that your heart was not pumping as well as it should.

We started you on water tablets called Furosemide. They will stop fluid collecting in your legs and lungs.

Please take 2 Furosemide tablets (2 x 40 mg = 80 mg) each morning and weigh yourself each morning.

If your weight drops by more than 2 kg over the week, reduce the dose to 1 tablet per day.

We have asked your GP practice to see you in about 2 weeks' time. They will take a blood test to check your kidney function.

We will see you in 6 weeks' time in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.

You will receive an appointment letter in the post.

Sincerely,
____

Dear ___,

During your recent hospitalization from March 1, 2024, to March 6, 2024, you were admitted with a chief complaint of severe chest pain, radiating to your left arm, accompanied by shortness of breath. Upon admission, an Electrocardiogram (ECG) confirmed the presence of an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), indicative of an acute transmural myocardial infarction of the anterior wall.

You underwent an urgent Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) with the placement of a stent to restore blood flow. Post-procedure, you remained stable, and no recurrent chest pain was noted during your time in the hospital. Your vitals were consistently stable following the intervention.

Throughout your stay, laboratory tests, including Troponin levels, initially showed elevation, with a peak approximately 12 hours after your admission. Subsequent tests indicated a steady decrease, which coincided with your reported improvement in condition and absence of complications. Your complete blood count (CBC) remained within normal limits, though lipid profile results demonstrated elevated LDL cholesterol.

To manage your cardiac condition, medications were prescribed as follows: Aspirin 325 mg once daily, Clopidogrel 75 mg once daily, and a statin at a dose of 40 mg once daily to manage cholesterol levels. Additionally, a beta-blocker, Metoprolol at 50 mg twice daily, and Lisinopril at 10 mg once daily as an ACE inhibitor were initiated. Intravenous Heparin was administered according to protocol during your stay, and Nitroglycerin was prescribed on an as-needed basis for any chest pain.

As of your discharge on March 6, 2024, you exhibited significant clinical improvement with resolved symptoms. Discharge instructions included comprehensive guidance on medication adherence and lifestyle modifications to support your recovery and long-term health. These modifications focus on a heart-healthy diet, gradual reintroduction of physical activity, smoking cessation, and effective stress management.

To ensure continued recovery and optimize your treatment plan, a follow-up appointment has been scheduled at the cardiology outpatient clinic on March 20, 2024. At this appointment, your recovery progress and medication management will be closely assessed.

Please adhere to the outlined lifestyle modifications and regularly attend follow-up appointments for optimal recovery. Should you experience any recurrent symptoms or have concerns regarding your treatment plan, we encourage you to contact your healthcare provider.

Wishing you a smooth and swift recovery.

Sincerely,

___  
(Signed on behalf of your medical team)
